Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and thanks to National
Pork Board for sponsoring this video!

Today I can't wait to share this recipe with
you because it is so perfect for the Summer

season, it is a crowd pleaser but it is also
perfect enough to make for the two of you
indoors if it's pouring out, like it is here.

We're going to make my smokey seared pork
chops that I'm going to serve with a Summer

corn succotash, it is a match made in food
heaven and I can't wait to share it with you.

Let me run you through the list of ingredients
you'll need for the pork and the rub.

So what I've got here are some really beautiful
boneless pork chops, now pork can take on

a variety of flavors and today I am going
to do a really lovely rub, I like to always

make extra rub because this is good on any
kind of pork, so say you're grilling for your

outdoor season, say you're doing BBQ ribs
or something like that, sprinkle this on top
and it's dynamite.

So in here, what we've got is smoked paprika,
brown sugar, cumin, ancho chili powder, dried
mustard, and granulated garlic.

You're going to mix everything together, and
now this like I said it's going to make extra,
but that's what we want.

I like to have it on hand, because you know
me, I like to have access to deliciousness

at my fingertips, so go haead and mix that
in and I'm also going to mix in a really good
pinch of salt right to the rub.

And then I'm going to just sprinkle both sides
of the pork chops with this rub, so you see

I'm using two pork chops here, for the two
of us, but you can definitely feed 6, 7, 8

people however many you want because guess
what, pork is pretty affordable, any cut of

pork is really affordable so it feeds people
really happily and it doesn't break the bank!
Which makes me very happy.

So I'm actually seasoning these first, even
though I'm just going to let them sit aside

for a few minutes while I take care of the
corn because I want the rub to really adhere

to my pork chop, so that's why I make sure
to season it on the sides, all over, because
I want every bite to be delicious.

So I'm just going to set these aside right
now, set them aside, I'm going to wash my
hands and then we work on our corn.

Alright, I've got a hot grill pan, like I
said you can do this on the outdoor grill,

say you're serving a lot of people on a weekend,
right?

You can make these on the outdoor grill and
it would be fabulous, but it's also quick

and easy to make inside, so I'm going to just
go ahead and char my corn on all sides and

my poblano pepper, and then I'll meet you
back here to make everything else and pull
it all together.

I charred my corn and then what I did was
I just took the kernels off the cob, I just

put a small bowl into a larger bowl and then
just sort of sliced it all the way down, it

comes off really easily and doesn't make a
mess.

I also went ahead and diced my poblano, make
sure to take out all of the seeds because

I don't want this to be too spicy, it's still
quite hard but this is when the next portion

comes in, what I've got back here is a skillet

to add the onions and the partially cooked
poblanos, and we're just going to go ahead

and let that cook for a few minutes until

hot I've got a drizzle of light olive oil
or any flavorless oil will do.

As you can see it's nice and smoky that's
what I want because I want a really beautiful
crust.

Now you guys know if you follow me on social
media, especially, that I cook pork chops

a lot for just Joe and I because it's just
a go-to, they're easy they're delicious, if

you cook them properly and you don't overcook
them they're really juicy and you don't have

to do a lot to them, which is why I love them,
and they're budget friendly, like I said which
makes me happy.

But you know, I think people when they think
of pork they think of that big portion of

meat that their grand-mom used to make on
a weekend I don't think they realize that

you can cook it much more small scale like
we do on a weekly basis, like I said, budget

friendly, cooks evenly, takes on a variety
of different flavors, what's not to love?

So I'm going to go ahead and keep an eye on

a couple of minutes, I want to make sure that

to keep an eye out on my onions and deliciousness

That is perfect, it's right at 145F, I'm going
to take this off.

Now most people think that when you're cooking
pork that you've got to cook until the juices

run clear, if you are using a muscle cut such
a like a tenderloin or a pork chop, pork is

best when you cook it to 145F or until the
juices run out like a blush pink color, it's

the most flavorful, delicious and safest when
it's cooked to 145F, so that is perfect, you

want to let this sit, look at that beautiful
crust, that is gorgeous, now I want to give
you a tip.

If you feel like your pork chop is too thick
and you're afraid of burning it on the stove

top, I just have a lot of patience because
I like to eat so I want to make sure my food's

good, so I just rotate them a lot, if you
don't want to do that just throw them into

a hot oven, you know, sear them first, get
that crust and then pop them into a 375F oven

for like 10-15 minutes or until it reaches
145F and then it's perfect every single time.

Now I'm just going to switch back to my skillet
